item.title: Baby Buffer Overflow - 32bit
item.author: cstef
item.description: Can you command this program to where it cannot go? To get the flag, you must somehow take control of its excecution. Is it even possible?

item.title: Backdoored Splunk II
item.author: Tyr
item.description:
You've probably seen Splunk being used for good, but have you seen it used for evil?
**NOTE: the focus of this challenge should be on the downloadable file below. It uses the dynamic service that is started, but you must put the puzzle pieces together to be retrieve the flag.**
**Download the file(s) below and press the `Start` button on the top-right to begin this challenge.**

item.title: Base-p-
item.author: Tyr
item.description:
That looks like a weird encoding, I wonder what it's based on.
Download the file(s) below.

item.title: Discount Programming Devices
item.author: glys
item.description: I used a tool on the internet to obfuscate my script! But I lost it, and I don't know how to get it back. Maybe you can help?

item.title: Echo Chamber
item.author: glys
item.description: Is anyone there? Is anyone there? I'm sending myself the flag! I'm sending myself the flag!

item.title: Finder's Fee
item.author: mango
item.description:
You gotta make sure the people who find stuff for you are rewarded well!
Escalate your privileges and uncover the flag.txt in the finder user's home directory.
Press the Start button in the top-right to begin this challenge. Connect with:
# Password is "userpass" ssh -p 30668 user@challenge.ctf.games

item.title: GoCrackMe1
item.author: glys
item.description:
TENNNNNN-HUT!
Welcome to the Go Dojo, gophers in training!
Go malware is on the rise. So we need you to sharpen up those Go reverse engineering skills. We've written three simple CrackMe programs in Go to turn you into Go-binary reverse engineering ninjas!
First up is the easiest of the three. Go get em!

item.title: GoCrackMe3
item.author: cstef
item.description: You've trained, you've failed, you've succeeded, you've learned. Everything you've done up to this point has prepared you for this moment. Don't let me down, Gopher. Don't let me down.

item.title: Malibu
item.author: cstef
item.description: What do you bring to the beach?

item.title: Mimi
item.author: mango
item.description:
Uh oh! Mimi forgot her password for her Windows laptop!
Luckily, she dumped one of the crucial processes running on her computer (don't ask me why, okay)... can you help her recover her password?
NOTE: Archive password is mimi

item.title: Mystery
item.author: Ary.eth
item.description:
Someone sent this to me... such enigma, such mystery:
rkenr wozec gtrfl obbur bfgma fkgyq ctkvq zeucz hlvwx yyzat zbvns kgyyd sthmi vsifc ovexl zzdqv slyir nwqoj igxuu kdqgr fdbbd njppc mujyy wwcoy
Settings as below:
3 Rotor Model Rotor 1: VI, Initial: A, Ring A Rotor 2: I, Initial: Q, Ring A Rotor 3: III, Initial L, Ring A Reflector: UKW B Plugboard: BQ CR DI EJ KW MT OS PX UZ GH

item.title: No need for Brutus
item.author: Ary.eth
item.description:
Author: @aenygma
A simple message for you to decipher:
squiqhyiiycfbudeduutvehrhkjki
Submit the original plaintext hashed with MD5, wrapped between the usual flag format: flag{}
Ex: If the deciphered text is "hello world", the MD5 hash would be 5eb63bbbe01eeed093cb22bb8f5acdc3, and the flag would be flag{5eb63bbbe01eeed093cb22bb8f5acdc3}.

item.title: OceanLocust
item.author: mango
item.description:
Wow-ee zow-ee!! Some advanced persistent threats have been doing some tricks with hiding payloads in image files!
We thought we would try our hand at it too.
NOTE: this challenge includes a debug build of the binary used to craft the image, as well as a release build... so you may choose to go an easier route or a harder route ;)

item.title: PillowFight
item.author: Tyr
item.description:
PillowFight uses _**advanced AI/MLRegressionLearning**_ to combine two images of your choosing
*note to investors this is not techically true at the moment we're using a python library but please give us money and we'll deliver it we promise.
**Press the `Start` button on the top-right to begin this challenge.**

item.title: Plantopia
item.author: Tyr
item.description:
Plantopia is our brand-new, cutting-edge plant care management website! Designed for hobbyists and professionals alike, it's your one-stop shop for all plant care needs.
Please perform a penetration test before our site launch and let us know if you find any issues.
Username: `testuser` Password: `testpassword`
**Press the `Start` button on the top-right to begin this challenge.**

item.title: Ran Somewhere
item.author: Ary.eth
item.description:
Thanks for joining the help desk! Here's your first ticket of the day; can you help the client out?
NOTE, this challenge uses a non-standard flag format. Enter the human-readable name of the location.

item.title: Russian Roulette
item.author: cstef
item.description: My PowerShell has been acting really weird!! It takes a few seconds to start up, and sometimes it just crashes my computer!?!?! :(

item.title: Rustline
item.author: cstef
item.description:
Jerry: A Redline Stealer. George: Written in Rust. Jerry: A Rusty Redline Stealer. George: A Rusty Redline Stealer, Jerry!
We caught a Redline variant executing on an endpoint and intercepted the encrypted files as they traversed the edge proxy. Well, everything except for the flag.txt file (imagine that...). Any chance you could figure out how this thing works and recover the flag? NOTE: Archive password is rustline

item.title: Strange Calc
item.author: cstef
item.description: I got this new calculator app from my friend! But it's really weird, for some reason it needs admin permissions to run??

item.title: Strive Marish Leadman TypeCDR
item.author: glys
item.description: Looks like primo hex garbage. Maybe something went wrong? Can you make sense of it?

item.title: System Code
item.author: mango
item.description:
Follow the white rabbit.
NOTE: Bruteforce is permitted for this challenge instance if you feel it is necessary.
Press the Start button on the top-right to begin this challenge.

item.title: The Void
item.author: ary.eth
item.description: When you gaze long into the void, the void gazes also into you...

item.title: TXT Message
item.author: Unknown
item.description: Hmmm, have you seen some of the strange DNS records for the ctf.games domain? One of them sure is odd...

item.title: X-RAY
item.author: glys
item.description: The SOC detected malware on a host, but antivirus already quarantined it... can you still make sense of what it does?

item.title: Y2J
item.author: glys
item.description:
Everyone was so worried about Y2K, but apparently it was a typo all along!!
The real world-ending fears were from Y2J!
